Ogugua "OG" Anunoby Jr. (born July 17, 1997) is an English-born Nigerian professional basketball player for the Toronto Raptors of the National Basketball Association. He played college basketball for the Indiana Hoosiers.

High School career[edit]

Anunoby played for Jefferson City High School.[1] During his senior season, he averaged 19.1 points and 8.6 rebounds per game and was named a finalist for Mr. Basketball in the state of Missouri.[2] He committed to Indiana University to play college basketball,[3] choosing the Hoosiers over Georgia, Iowa, George Mason, and Ole Miss.

College career[edit]

Freshman year[edit]

As a freshman at Indiana, he appeared in 34 games, averaging 4.9 points, 2.6 rebounds and 0.5 assists per game.[4][5]

Sophomore year[edit]

Anunoby was selected as a Preseason All-American by The Sporting News.[6] Anunoby injured his right knee against Penn State on January 18, 2017, causing him to undergo season-ending knee surgery.[7] On April 10, 2017, Anunoby formally declared his intentions to enter the the 2017 NBA Draft and hire an agent, formally ending his tenure with the Hoosiers.[8]

College statistics[edit]

Source:[9]

Professional career[edit]

Toronto Raptors (2017–present)[edit]

On June 22, 2017, Anunoby was selected with the 23rd overall pick in the 2017 NBA draft by the Toronto Raptors.

Personal life[edit]

Anunoby was born in London, England and raised in Jefferson City, Missouri, where his father is a professor at Lincoln University.[10] His brother, Chigbo Anunoby, has played for the Cleveland Browns, Tennessee Titans and Minnesota Vikings, of the National Football League.
